REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
(Case of Sardara Singh)


    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That this Assembly doth agree with the Committee of Privileges in their Report as contained in Paper L.A. 10 of 1962.

    Sir, this Report ---

    Mr David Marshall: I rise on a point of order, Mr Speaker, Sir ---

    Mr Speaker: Point of order.

    Mr David Marshall: --- whether it is proper, in the light of the motion passed by this Assembly on Friday limiting certain items of business up to Wednesday night, to introduce new items during the course of these sittings, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: It is in order under the Standing Orders.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, this Report deals with the matter which the Member for Anson had wanted to raise in this Assembly on the case of Sardara Singh, former Acting Sergeant in the Singapore Police Force. Subsequently it came to my knowledge that the Member for Anson was also a solicitor for the said Sardara Singh, and I drew your attention to the fact that (his could probably be committed to the Committee of Privileges for investigation. The Committee has met and produced this Report. It has been agreed that if the Member for Anson had raised the matter of the case of Sardara Singh in the Assembly and in the manner he proposed he could have come within the mischief indicated in the preceding paragraphs and could have been dealt with accordingly for abuse of privilege or for dishonourable conduct.

    However, the Committee investigated also the desirability of framing a general

Column: 5

resolution to cover the matters raised but considered that in the light of the above it was not necessary to do so.

    Mr Speaker, when a person has acquired three "P.s" to his name - meaning, privilege, profit and power - he is virtually in an unassailable position. During the debate on the amendments to the Advocates and Solicitors Ordinance, the Member for Anson admitted that an advocate and solicitor was in a special position of privilege and also in a position of profit. Here I would like to add that when an advocate and solicitor also becomes an Assemblyman, particularly if he is on the Opposition Bench where he does not have to bear responsibilities, he also acquires his third P. - meaning that he acquires power.

    Now, normally a member of the Bar would be responsible to the body that controls his profession, which is the Bar Committee. The Bar Committee can haul a fellow member over the coals if there has been a breach of etiquette. But if an advocate and solicitor is also a Member of the Assembly, and he is given liberty to speak in this Assembly on matters which probably touch upon his professional work, he would be in a position not only to enlarge his profit from the advertisement he gains in this Assembly but also he would be in a position of power. However, such a person could not be disciplined by the Bar Committee. Under the Powers and Immunities Ordinance of Assemblymen, such an advocate and solicitor cannot be hauled over the coals by his professional body. However, it does not mean that we should allow a person to exercise his power and his privilege in an unrestrained manner. If a professional body is powerless to discipline its member by virtue of the fact that he is also a Member of the Assembly, then it is up to this House itself to discipline its own Members.

    Parliamentary democracy can only succeed, Mr Speaker, if Assemblymen exercise restraint and self-discipline. If there is absolute licence of speech and if there is any attempt to get away with the penalties for which he would nominally be guilty of if he were outside the Assembly, it would mean, Mr

Column: 6

Speaker, that the reputation of this Assembly would be brought down to a very low level.

    Mr David Marshall: Umm ---

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: I hear a grunt from the Member for Anson. But I am quite sure that he in his uprighteousness does want to uphold parliamentary democracy. I know he tries very hard to restrain himself at times, but, as they say, the body is weaker than the spirit. However, the lesson which we wish to draw from this Report is this, Mr Speaker, and that is that Assemblymen, especially those who are professional men, in particular advocates and solicitors, must remember that they are in a position of privilege, profit and power, and commensurate with these special qualities that they have acquired they should also exercise equal responsibility.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    Question proposed.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, there is an air of unreality in discussing privilege and the dignity of the House in the context of the throes of the struggle for the survival of democracy itself through which we are going today. I shall not be long, Sir, nor shall I seek to contest this ruling particularly in the light of the fact that every minute we are discussing this we are taking away that much time from a much more crucial question which is subject to a guillotine provision.

    I would like to draw attention to one or two points, Sir, just for the record. It is inaccurate to suggest that there was anything but a willingness and desire on my part that this matter should be clarified. Having come across some vital information which I considered would affect the view of this House in respect of certain matters concerning the administrative conduct of statutory provisions, I had wished that this House should know of it, after my client had ceased to be my client and he had left this country and the result of whatever took place here could have no effect on him. When I gave that indication, I learned that the Deputy Prime Minister

Column: 7

and the Leader of the House was unhappy as he thought that I might contravene the privilege provisions. If you will remember, Sir, I had indicated that in those circumstances I would wish, rather than speak on it and possibly contravene any privilege provisions, that the matter should be considered by the Committee of Privileges.

    I am delighted that you saw fit to consult the Fourth Clerk at the Table in the House of Commons and I find myself in complete agreement with his stand as indicated in paragraph 10:

    'I think that it might be accepted as a broad general principle that a Member would be in contempt (of the House) if his advocacy in Parliament of a matter in which he had been professionally engaged was in any way proved to be due to a desire to show that he was continuing to give value for the fee marked on his brief. If, however, his parliamentary activities were completely divorced from a furtherance of his lay client's interests at law, there would seem to be no objection.'

And in point of fact, Sir, that was my stand.

    However, I can understand the unhappy position in which the Committee found itself where it received the memoranda and representations from the Bar Committee. I refer to the Chairman of the Bar Committee who was asked what if a Member of the Bar in the course of his professional duties learned of matters of national importance and thereafter ceased to act and had his client's permission. And he said that it would be objectionable still. One can only believe that that was his view because he is not a national of this State and it had no reality in the context of his representations. But he says in paragraph 16 that the Bar Committee would still take objection:

    'I would still take objection because it seems it could be deemed that the lawyer mentioning this matter would be seeking to attract trade by advertisement.'

Sir, my view is very simply this. If it can at any time be shown that a member of the Bar who is an Assemblyman has acted whether within or without this Assembly utilising his position in the Assembly for purposes of furthering his client's interests or for purposes of furthering his personal interests in attracting

Column: 8

trade, then he has acted in a grossly improper fashion - whatever name you may call it by - under the Privileges and Immunities Ordinance of this House, Sir. But where it is completely divorced from any ulterior motive of that character, then there can be no question, as the Fourth Clerk at the Table of the House of Commons said. But I do not wish to lengthen this debate. I shall move no amendments, Sir, I merely wish to record that I am happy that no general principle has been enunciated by the Select Committee which could fetter future Assemblies. I take note that the Select Committee went no further than to say that if I had raised it, and had my conduct been of a certain character in the presentation of the Sardara Singh case, I could have been brought up. I shall not bring it up. In the context of the composition of this House, I shall not take that risk.

2.47 p.m.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I am glad the Member for Anson at least has accepted in principle the Report of this Committee of Privileges and the assurance that he, for one, opposes any attempt by any advocate and solicitor to utilise his position in this Assembly for further gain and profit outside. I am sure that is a sentiment which Members of this House will agree with, and I have nothing further to say to it.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Resolved,

    That this Assembly doth agree with the Committee of Privileges in their Report as contained in Paper L.A. 10 of 1962.

TARIFF ADVISORY COMMISSION BILL
(As reported from Select Committee)


    Order for Third Reading read.

2.48 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Third time."

    When I moved the Second Reading of the Bill, Mr Speaker, Sir, I had a feeling that this Bill might well arouse

Column: 9

a raging controversy between the Singapore traders on the one hand and the Singapore manufacturers on the other. This Bill seeks to regulate the manner in which a Tariff Advisory Commission is to conduct its investigations on any proposals to impose tariffs in Singapore. As such, therefore, the Bill seeks to change from time to time the free port status of Singapore. There was an expectation then that a controversy might rage between the upholders of a 100 per cent free port status of Singapore on the one hand, and the manufacturers who want to see new industries as fast as possible on the other hand.

    When the Bill was sent to Select Committee, the usual processes were set on foot, including advertisements in the papers asking for views of interested parties. A strange thing then happened. There was absolutely no response to these advertisements and the closing date for reception of memoranda had to be extended. Finally, two parties made their submissions, namely, the Joint Chambers of Commerce, who were somewhat apprehensive of the provisions of this Bill, and the Singapore Manufacturers' Association, who welcomed the general provisions of the Bill.

    We had a fairly cordial and friendly discussion with the interested parties in Select Committee, as a result of which two amendments were introduced and approved by Select Committee. May I draw the attention of the House to these two amendments? They are in clause 6. There is an addition to clause 6 and the additional sentence reads as follows - I should mention that clause 6 allows the Commission to co-opt, on an ad hoc basis, two or more persons with special knowledge of the subject at the inquiry. An amendment was made to this clause to allow and, in fact, to make it compulsory that one of these persons shall represent industrial interests and the other shall represent trading interests. This amendment was made after the Select Committee heard the views of the representors and agreed that they had a strong case. So clause 6 contains this additional sentence which reads:

    `At least one of such persons shall be a person representing industrial interests and

Column: 10

one other shall be a person representing trading interests.'

    The other amendment occurs in clause 9 (2) (a) (ii) in page A3, line 27 of the Report of the Select Committee on the Bill. This gives effect to the proposal tabled by the Member for Tanglin who desires that the Commission should investigate, among other things, the effect of tariffs on the general level of employment in Singapore. And this, I think, Members of the House will agree is a completely unexceptional request and accordingly the Government agrees to the inclusion of this amendment.

    The other clauses do not call for any comment from me at this stage as they have been dealt with adequately, I think, on the Second Reading.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Third time and passed.

CUSTOMS (AMENDMENT) BILL
(As reported from Select Committee)


    Order for Third Reading read.

2.54 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Third time."

    This Bill is for the most part consequential on the passage of the Tariff Advisory Commission Bill. But in Select Committee, I took the opportunity of proposing certain amendments which were accepted and these amendments dealt with the quantum of draw-back which local cigarette manufacturers may receive on the export of their cigarettes overseas. PUBLIC UTILITIES BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.55 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation to proceed with this Bill. I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, this Bill, together with the complementary Local Government Integration Bill, which will be moved by my colleague, the Minister for Finance, has been drafted to carry out the P.A.P.'s programme of unified administration as outlined in The Tasks Ahead. Therein we pointed out the peculiar position in Singapore of two parallel administrations - the Central Government and the City Council - existing side by side and duplicating each other's functions and activities. We were against such a wasteful and expensive system of government for such a small island and proposed to rationalise the administrative structure.

    Sir, the implementation of this policy of integration was phased in three stages:

    1. The administrative integration of the City Council Departments into relevant Ministries of the Government.

    2. The financial integration which was completed with the coming into operation on the 1st of January, 1961, of the Property Tax Ordinance and the Local Government Financial Integration Ordinance. These two Bills, the Public Utilities Bill and the Local Government Integration Bill, will mark the fruition of our policy of unified administration.

    When this Bill comes into force and the Public Utilities Board is established, integration will be legally completed.

    Sir, incorporated in this Bill are those sections of the Local Government Ordinance, 1957, which are applicable to the three trading departments of electricity, water, gas and their duties, powers and responsibilities. Regard is also being paid to the relevant legislation, including the Federation of Malaya Electricity Ordinance, 1949, the

Column: 12

Housing and Development Ordinance, 1959, and the Singapore Telephone Board Ordinance.

    The Explanatory Statement adequately indicates the intention and purpose of the Bill. As it is the intention to refer this Bill together with other related Bills involved in this exercise of integration to a Select Committee to allow for careful study before enactment, I do not propose to elaborate on the detailed provisions of this Bill.

    Sir, the purpose of sending it to Select Committee is in order to allow all interested parties to make their representations. It may well be, Mr Speaker, Sir, that these representations will entail a redrafting of the Bill when it is submitted to the House again later in the new Session after the Assembly has been adjourned sine die and prorogued.

    Question proposed.

2.59 p.m.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): There is just one provision in the Bill, Mr Speaker, Sir, on which I would like to touch, which seems to involve the question of principle, and the principle is one which affects the authority of the Assembly. Mr Speaker, Sir, the power to borrow money as set out in the various clauses here seems, in some way, to infringe upon the rights of the Assembly in so far as the monies of the State are concerned. Take clause 23 onwards, Mr Speaker, Sir. There is no doubt that the Board must be given ample powers to borrow money and, as such, it must be able to fix its rate of interest and the terms and conditions upon which repayment will be effected. I fully appreciate all that. I also appreciate that the Board will be in a very different position from what the City Council was, because the City Council was an institution which had been in existence for some considerable time. It had property of its own and all the loans which were raised by the City Council for its public utility undertakings were a charge upon all the assets of the City Council. That being so, it was possible to induce the investing

Column: 13

public to take up those loans. But the Board will naturally be in a different position. All its assets will be assets which are not marketable assets, and therefore the borrowing powers to that extent will be largely hampered from a security point of view. Therefore, it is necessary that these loans should be underwritten by the Government. I fully appreciate that. But there is a provision in the Bill which says that if the revenues of the Board are insufficient to meet payments from these loan liabilities either incurred in the past or in the future, then they shall be a charge on the public debt of Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as you know, under the Constitution, any charge on the public debt is not an item arguable in this Assembly. It is an item of statutory expenditure which the Government automatically gets. This is a question of principle which, I think, the Assembly is rightly interested in, although I do appreciate the difficulties of the situation. The position could arise, Mr Speaker, Sir, that a great deal of money could be borrowed by the Board, naturally with the consent of the Minister, and yet the Assembly would find itself unable to do anything about it because any expenditure in the way of repayment will be a public debt. The Assembly will be powerless. I do not know what the solution is; perhaps the Minister might think of one, but I raise it as a matter which concerns the rights of the Legislative Assembly.

3.03 p.m.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng (Mountbatten): Mr Speaker, Sir, with regard to clause 19, I would like the Government, or the Select Committee when it sits, to pay attention to it. It may sound to be a matter of detail, Mr Speaker, Sir, but it is a detail that is causing hardship to a very large number of poor people in Singapore. So perhaps the Select Committee will pay attention to this detail.

    Clause 19 provides that the Board may cut off supply in default of payment. I do know of people, especially those occupying S.I.T. flats, who are asked to pay a deposit of $40/- or

Column: 14

thereabouts. Now, if for months and months they have used these facilities to the sum of $7/- or $8/-, they would still have a balance of $32/- on deposit. But by virtue of clause 19, immediately they default payment for the first time, although they have a big deposit left there, they will still be deprived of their supplies. And to get their supplies resumed, they will have to pay not only what they are asked at that time but also the expenses incurred by the Board in so cutting off the supplies and resuming them.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I heard the hon Member say it was a matter for the Select Committee. I think she has made her point, and perhaps she will send a memorandum to the Select Committee on this particular point.

3.04 p.m.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in moving the Second Reading debate on this Bill, the Prime Minister said that the Government dealt with the third stage of the integration of the local government with the Singapore Government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, with this Public Utilities Bill the establishment of the Public Utilities Board will change the situation in Singapore and that of all the people in Singapore. It will also affect the procedures in public utilities. We hope the supply of gas, water and electricity from the Board will be complete and better than at present.

    I would also like the Prime Minister to assure the House that the establishment of the Public Utilities Board will not increase the expenses of the people of Singapore in regard to water and gas supplies. I would like him to ensure, too, that he would not increase the charges for water, gas and electricity because this will greatly affect the people of Singapore, especially the common people.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, you have seen that before the establishment of the Housing and Development Board, i.e. during the time of the S.I.T., the rents fixed at that time were not as high as those

Column: 15

after the establishment of the Housing and Development Board. So after the establishment of the Public Utilities Board, will this Board take the same step as the Housing and Development Board and increase the charges for water, gas, and electricity supplies? I hope the Prime Minister will give an assurance to the House that the charges for electricity, gas and water will not be increased in future.

    Mr Speaker, from this Bill we can also see that the past City Council staff, i.e. those who worked in the Gas, Electricity and Water Departments, will be integrated and transferred to the Public Utilities Board. We hope the staff at present in the three Departments will enjoy the same benefits even after they have been integrated.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we welcome the commitment of this Bill to a Select Committee. We hope the Select Committee will consider in greater detail the opinions of the people concerned and also will arrive at conclusions more beneficial to the people.

3.10 p.m.

A large sum of money will probably have to be borrowed from the World Bank for extensive expansion of both our power supply and our waterworks. Therefore, the views of the World Bank as to the proper safeguards and provisos that there should be in the statutory provisions regulating the conduct of the Board are of some importance to us.

    Sir, I do not wish to go into details regarding this. Needless to say, the World Bank, before it advances large sums of money which may well amount to over $100 million altogether, would want to be assured that there are sufficient guarantees on repayment and certain guarantees on the proper conduct of the business of the Board.

    As for the points made by the Member for Choa Chu Kang, I think they

are not worth any specific replies. Nobody has ever moved any Bill in this Assembly by which charges have gone up, to the detriment of the public, or by which the conditions of service of the employees of the Government Departments who have been transferred to the Board have been worsened. I think they are the usual propaganda points made over and over again in the hope that they may win votes. I do not think we are losing any, and so I shall not bother to reply.

    Sir, I beg to move.

LOCAL GOVERNMENT INTEGRATION BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

3.13 p.m.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, I have His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's recommendation to proceed with this Bill. I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    You will recall, Sir, at the Budget session last year I mentioned that the integration of the City Council into the Central Government was a major administrative reform undertaken by the People's Action Party Government. I touched at some length on the make-up of the City Council and the manner in which it was proposed to integrate it into the Central Government. Since 1st January, 1961, the physical integration of the City Council other than the three trading departments has been in progress, and administratively and operationally they have been absorbed by various Government Ministries. This major administrative reform is in accordance with the pledge of the Party to bring about a smoother and more efficient public service to serve the people of the State. In the process, duplication of functions that had previously

Column: 17

existed has been removed, and it is expected that in the long run economies will be effected and efficiency raised.

    Sir, the Bill before the House is complementary to the Public Utilities Bill which was earlier moved for a Second Reading by the Prime Minister, and it provides for the transfer to the Government with retrospective effect from the 1st January, 1961, of all assets as well as liabilities and employees of the City Council and of the Rural Board other than those transferred to the Public Utilities Board for the running of water, gas, and electricity undertakings. These are contained in Part I of the Bill. It also enacts in Parts II to VI and VIII all provisions of the Local Government Ordinance, 1957, relating to streets, sewage, public health, etc . - matters which hitherto have been within the jurisdiction of the City Council and the Rural Board - and vests the necessary statutory powers in Government officers.

    The only new legislation is in Part VII which establishes District Offices and gives certain powers to District Officers.

    The enactment of this Bill will formally complete the Government's policy of integrating local authorities into the central administration. Since it is proposed to refer the Bill to Select Committee for closer examination and since the Explanatory Statement gives the objects and reasons of the Bill, I shall confine my remarks to two important aspects of the Bill: namely those concerning personnel and finance.

    The Bill provides that all employees of the City Council who are not transferred to the Public Utilities Board shall be transferred to the service of the Government at the same rate of pay or as near as may be the same conditions of service as those on which they were employed by the City Council. Upon the coming into operation of this Ordinance, these employees will become Government servants and will legally be governed by Government regulations and by the Constitution. But it is our intention, in so far as salaries are concerned, that all serving employees on the permanent establishment of the City

Column: 18

Council shall be allowed to retain, if they so desire, their existing salaries and salary scales on their transfer to the Government service.

    With regard to other terms and conditions of service, it is hoped, in consultation with the Staff Unions concerned, to bring about a set of conditions of service that would be acceptable and which would be patterned on the terms and conditions now applicable to Government servants. It is envisaged that in the process certain minor adjustments and changes may be necessary.

    The Bill also provides that persons transferred from the City Council who are already members of the Municipal Provident Fund will continue in membership of that Fund. In addition, such persons who are eligible for membership of the Fund at the time of transfer to the Government service will retain that eligibility. Officers of the City Council who are not members of the Municipal Provident Fund nor are eligible for membership thereof will be governed by the Pensions and Central Provident Fund Ordinances in every respect as they are applicable to Government servants. Persons appointed after the coming into force of this Bill will, of course, be governed by the Pensions Ordinance and the Central Provident Fund Ordinance. The management of the Municipal Provident Fund will be transferred to the Government together with all its assets and liabilities, and the accounts thereof will be kept by the Accountant-General. The assets and liabilities connected with the public loans of the City Council, including the sinking fund for those loans, are to be transferred to the Public Utilities Board under the Public Utilities Bill, but the Government will contribute to the Board in respect of those portions of outstanding public loans which were used to buy assets to be transferred to the Government under this Bill.

    As I said earlier, the only new provision in this Bill is the establishment of District Offices. The principal function of District Officers is to ensure the adequacy of various services provided in the districts, to receive representations, and generally to act as liaison
